text.headline: Tony Hillerman Born
text.text: Anthony Grove Hillerman born in Sacred Heart, Oklahoma to August and Lucy Hillerman, a farming family of German heritage.

events.notes: Grew up in rural Oklahoma among Potawatomi people, which sparked his lifelong interest in Native American cultures.

text.headline: Enlists in U.S. Army
text.text: Hillerman enlists in the U.S. Army during World War II, serving with the 103rd Infantry Division.

events.notes: His wartime experiences, including being wounded in France, profoundly influenced his later writing.

text.headline: Graduates University of Oklahoma
text.text: Earns a degree in journalism from the University of Oklahoma, beginning his career as a reporter.

events.notes: His journalism background shaped his meticulous attention to detail in his novels.

text.headline: Moves to New Mexico
text.text: Hillerman moves to New Mexico to work at the Santa Fe New Mexican newspaper, deepening his connection to the Southwest.

events.notes: This move immersed him in Navajo and Pueblo cultures that would become central to his fiction.

text.headline: The Blessing Way
text.text: First novel published, introducing Lieutenant Joe Leaphorn of the Navajo Tribal Police investigating a murder connected to witchcraft fears.

events.notes: Initially rejected by publishers who thought readers wouldn't be interested in Native American characters.

text.headline: Dance Hall of the Dead
text.text: Second Leaphorn novel explores the disappearance of a Zuni boy and the clash between Navajo and Zuni cultures.

events.notes: This novel won the Edgar Award for Best Novel, establishing Hillerman as a major mystery writer.

text.headline: Edgar Award - Best Novel
text.text: Hillerman wins the prestigious Edgar Award from Mystery Writers of America for Dance Hall of the Dead.

events.notes: The Edgar Award is considered the most prestigious award in mystery writing, named after Edgar Allan Poe.

text.headline: Listening Woman
text.text: Third Leaphorn novel features a blind medicine woman as a witness to events surrounding a murder and hidden treasure.

events.notes: Deepens exploration of traditional Navajo spiritual practices and healing ceremonies.

text.headline: People of Darkness
text.text: Introduces Officer Jim Chee, a young Navajo Tribal Police officer training to become a medicine man. Explores uranium mining and corporate crime.

events.notes: Chee represents the younger generation navigating between traditional ways and modern life.

text.headline: The Dark Wind
text.text: Jim Chee investigates drug smuggling on the Hopi-Navajo border, featuring a windmill and violated burial site.

events.notes: Explores the complex relationship between Hopi and Navajo peoples sharing disputed land.

text.headline: The Ghostway
text.text: Chee tracks a witness from the reservation to Los Angeles, contrasting urban and reservation life while exploring ghost sickness.

events.notes: One of the few novels that takes the action off the reservation, highlighting cultural displacement.

text.headline: Skinwalkers
text.text: First novel featuring both Leaphorn and Chee working together. Witchcraft accusations mask deeper crimes in the community.

events.notes: The pairing of the skeptical Leaphorn with the traditional Chee became the series' signature dynamic.

text.headline: Special Friend of the Dineh Award
text.text: The Navajo Tribal Council honors Hillerman with the Special Friend of the Dineh (Navajo people) Award.

events.notes: A remarkable honor for a non-Native writer, recognizing his respectful portrayal of Navajo culture.

text.headline: A Thief of Time
text.text: A missing archaeologist leads Leaphorn and Chee into the world of Anasazi ruins, pot hunting, and obsession with the past.

events.notes: Addresses the controversial issue of archaeological looting on Native lands.

text.headline: Talking God
text.text: A Smithsonian repatriation dispute brings Leaphorn and Chee to Washington D.C. involving masks, museum politics, and an assassination plot.

events.notes: Written before NAGPRA (1990), this novel presciently addressed Native artifact repatriation issues.

text.headline: Coyote Waits
text.text: An officer is killed and an elderly shaman is the prime suspect. The investigation uncovers connections to Butch Cassidy legends and historical truth.

events.notes: Explores how stories and myths shape our understanding of history and justice.

text.headline: Grand Master Award
text.text: Mystery Writers of America names Hillerman a Grand Master, the organization's highest honor for lifetime achievement.

events.notes: Only a handful of mystery writers have received this honor, including Agatha Christie and Raymond Chandler.

text.headline: Sacred Clowns
text.text: A Koshare ceremonial clown is murdered at a pueblo, leading to investigations involving gambling, school politics, and pueblo secrets.

events.notes: Features Bernie Manuelito in an early appearance before her expanded role in later books.

text.headline: The Fallen Man
text.text: A skeleton discovered on Ship Rock opens a decade-old disappearance case involving land rights and climbing taboos.

events.notes: Ship Rock (Tsé Bitʼaʼí) is sacred to the Navajo; climbing it violates traditional beliefs.

text.headline: The First Eagle
text.text: A murdered biologist researching plague on the reservation leads to conflicts between Hopi prophecy and Western science.

events.notes: Addresses real public health issues on the reservation while respecting traditional beliefs.

text.headline: Hunting Badger
text.text: A casino heist with militia connections leads to a manhunt through the canyon country of the Four Corners region.

events.notes: Inspired by actual events and the rugged terrain that makes law enforcement challenging.

text.headline: Center of the American West Award
text.text: University of Colorado honors Hillerman with the Wallace Stegner Award for his contributions to Western American literature.

events.notes: Named after the great Western author Wallace Stegner, recognizing Hillerman's literary significance.

text.headline: The Wailing Wind
text.text: Leaphorn returns from retirement to investigate a cold case involving a legendary lost gold mine and a murdered con man.

events.notes: Features Leaphorn's continued involvement despite his official retirement.

text.headline: The Sinister Pig
text.text: A body found near a pipeline leads to a complex investigation involving border politics, energy development, and federal agencies.

events.notes: Addresses contemporary issues of border security and energy development on Native lands.

text.headline: Skeleton Man
text.text: A decades-old plane crash over the Grand Canyon resurfaces, connecting to diamond smuggling and ancestral remains.

events.notes: Based on the real 1956 Grand Canyon mid-air collision, the worst aviation disaster of its time.

text.headline: The Shape Shifter
text.text: Hillerman's final novel brings closure as Leaphorn pursues a cold case involving a legendary Navajo rug, arson, and revenge.

events.notes: Published two years before Hillerman's death, it serves as a fitting conclusion to the series.

text.headline: Tony Hillerman Dies
text.text: Tony Hillerman dies in Albuquerque, New Mexico at age 83, leaving a legacy of 18 Leaphorn and Chee novels.

events.notes: His daughter Anne Hillerman continues the series, honoring his legacy with new novels.
